reviews.review_text: Fascinating new perspective on Second World War and use of drugs by German military and political leaders,  The benefits they gained from use of crystal meths was essential for the rapid victories in 1940-1 but produced enormous negative effects as the war dragged on. The detailed exposure of Hitler's drug addictions was presented in a lucid convincing argument.
Very interesting and a great insight into the third reich
An amazing account on the use of drugs by Hitler and the German forces during the 2nd world war

Fascinating suggestion and partial explanation for what could have possibly moved a country in this direction. Very interesting distinction between the Hitler who came to power and the Hitler who lost power, as well as potential motivations and actions of the people around him.

I am a doctor. I know addiction too well.  I love history. Reading this book and the evidence provided I suddenly begin to realize why the downfall of the German Reich never made sense to me - until now!
Very interesting. It all adds up now. Thank god it went the way it did.
Fascinating idea, the idea alone is worth 5 stars. However, although well researched some conclusions seem a bit of a reach, and the book does drag overall, hammering the same points over and over.
For those who wish to understand how the powers at be get the little guy in the street to pick up arms and defend the motherland against all logic, this is the book you should not miss.
Excellent insights and revelations. Rambles a little towards the end and becomes a little repetitive but over all eye opening.

summary:
The sensational German bestseller on the overwhelming role of drug-taking in the Third Reich, from Hitler to housewives. 

The Nazis presented themselves as warriors against moral degeneracy. Yet, as Norman Ohler's gripping bestseller reveals, the entire Third Reich was permeated with drugs: cocaine, heroin, morphine and, most of all, methamphetamines, or crystal meth, used by everyone from factory workers to housewives, and crucial to troops' resilience - even partly explaining German victory in 1940.

The promiscuous use of drugs at the very highest levels also impaired and confused decision-making, with Hitler and his entourage taking refuge in potentially lethal cocktails of stimulants administered by the physician Dr Morell as the war turned against Germany. While drugs cannot on their own explain the events of the Second World War or its outcome, Ohler shows, they change our understanding of it. Blitzed forms a crucial missing piece of the story.

'Extremely interesting ... a serious piece of scholarship, very well researched' Ian Kershaw
